content: The Emancipation Proclamation was significant in the Civil War as it declared that all slaves in Confederate states would be considered free. Although it didn't immediately free any slaves and was only applicable in areas of the country under Confederate control, it helped to shift the focus of the war towards the abolition of slavery. The proclamation also had a profound impact on the morale of African American soldiers who were allowed to join the Union Army and fight against slavery. It also made it more difficult for foreign nations, such as Great Britain, to support the Confederacy because of its connection to slavery. Ultimately, the Emancipation Proclamation paved the way for the 13th Amendment to the US Constitution, which finally abolished slavery in the United States.
